comments.commentBody: We used black eyed peas and kale (couldn't find mustard greens), and this recipe is fantastic! With cornbread it was perfect!

Deadline,

One of the hit albums of 1969 was titled "Switched-On Bach," by the artist known at the time as Walter Carlos, who later became Wendy Carlos. It consisted of Moog synthesizer realizations of J. S. Bach selections, and became a runaway sensation. A sort of precursor to "Hooked On Classics" without the pop rhythm section.

I was going to post a clip, but YouTube is so infested with knock-offs and home-grown tributes masquerading as "Switched-On Bach" and everything related, it's impossible to find Carlos's original recordings.

As for MTFT, I agree. I always enjoy Tobin's remarks. The person I referenced in particular wasn't him, but I'll leave it at that as I've already ventured all to far into personal sniping, which I shouldn't be doing. Sorry.

Thanks, Alan.

I remember something like that from around that time, but I don't remember the name(s) of the performer, and I'm pretty sure I 'm thinking of something else.

Also, my comment was about the person that MTFT referred to as the "person," not about MTFT. Sorry I wasn't clear. Anyway, I quite enjoy the comments and discussions, whether considered corrections or explansions/clarifications. Yours too.

.
Any reference to me in this thread is taken as benevolent and humourous. No one need worry that I was offended. As for fact-checks, people who find them to be downers should abandon this Reply now.

From the following weekend's Corrections page (search online for the terms in the following):

"The crossword puzzle on Saturday provided an erroneous clue for 34-Down, seeking the answer “Marcellus.” The clue should have read, “Roman consul who captured Syracuse in 211 B.C.” — not “A.D. 211.” The puzzle also provided an erroneous clue for 34-Across, seeking the answer “MSN.” The clue should have read, “Co. behind Hotmail starting in 1997” — not “It launched Hotmail in ‘96.” (While Hotmail was launched in 1996, it was not owned by Microsoft, which runs the MSN web portal, until 1997.)"

I truly admire the passive voice evident there. "The puzzle provided an erroneous clue."

Never mind that the team of humans responsible for each crossword is only about half as large as the Editorial Board's membership.

Martin is (sincerely) without sin in this instance.

The first four of tonight's comments (being the only ones when I began writing this) were basically fact checks. That's a good thing, of course. I often do the same myself. But it certainly starts the night's read on a rather "downer" tone. I for one enjoyed the puzzle, and I don't mind saying so.

Yes, we have T. J. MAXX around this part of the country, though I'm not conversant with its wares nor Kohl's. But I've heard of them both, so I'll assume they are comparable enough for the cluing.

Here's my "downer": I'm a bit surprised to see ARIE, Italian plural form for "arias," clued by a Viennese operetta (originally written in German, though I've often heard it sung in English). Seems a little odd. I've never heard an English-speaking participant in operas, operettas, oratorios, or cantatas refer to them in the plural as anything but "arias." Maybe that's just me.

For 27D, how about this: "He was switched on by Carlos in 1969." (Maybe a bit obscure anymore.)

I made this for the first time this evening and it was fabulous! I used 4% milk fat cottage cheese, Half and
Half for the milk and a very nice sharp white cheddar for the cheese. I weighed out the dry noodles and mixed according to the instructions. I kept it in the oven about 5 minutes longer to get a nice browned, crunchy top. Served with steamed broccoli and roasted chicken. Yum! Will be making this again.

So, you're going with the "there's no difference between the left and right", except that there is actually a difference, the right has never seen a wealthy privilege it doesn't like, and the left--even the wealthy left-- is proposing to restrain it.

This is essentially a tautology: "Adelson has every right to fund whatever lawful causes he wishes". The question is what should be lawful?

(We also might question whether Adelson's wealth came to him through lawful means, but leave that aside for now.)

You can make this for the same day and still get rave reviews if you did not make it the night before.  All the gruyere seemed to float to the top, creating a delicious golden cheesy crust - it might be a reason to make in advance as the instructions call for so the cheese is more present throughout.  It's a very rich taste yet fluffy mouthfeel - did anyone try with bacon instead of sausage, thinking might be more of a contrast with the buttery croissants?

In my limited experience with cancer, the problems with cancer treatment aren't a lack of drugs for early-stage cancers (which are generally get first-line standard treatment based upon cancers of that particular subtype).

A real issue is that there is insufficient priority placed upon rapid diagnosis and treatment. Britain instituted a "Two Week Rule" regarding suspected melanoma, where suspected melanoma are subjected to a full and complete excision, most usually immediately, but always by this rule, within two weeks of detection. Studies performed in Britain as well as those written up by the NIH have demonstrated 5-year survival rates that have cut the percentage of fatalities in half because of this rule. (82% survival compared to 62%) Nevertheless, even though Britain has made this the standard of care in 2000, fifteen years later, the US has failed to take this rule up.

I recently had a loved one found with a suspected melanoma, and we as a family struggled with the US medical system to get it treated according to this British standard of care. It was impossible, because doctors don't give priority to suspected melanoma, so we waited for treatment behind patients that had more definitive diagnoses, and because the suspected melanoma was diagnosed with a punch biopsy that provides insufficient information for precise staging based upon Breslow thickness and fails to remove tumors that may still metastasize while waiting for definitive treatment.

401K plans generate fees, but nothing like the hedge funds and derivative garbage that public pension funds invest in.   The fees on hedge funds are the infamous 2/20 fees--2% annually of the principal invested and 20% of any investment gains.

"Most currently have inadequate 401(k)-type accounts or no retirement account at all."

For most workers, 401(k) plans serve the financial industry by generating lucrative management fees. That was their unspoken purpose right from the start. Unlike the old defined-benefit plans, 401(k)'s are defined-contribution plans, which means the worker contributes money to the market's liquidity with no guarantee of getting any money for retirement.

The last guest just left. A week of cooking put to good use.

I worked at a site in Germany near Ritter Sport, which really makes chocolate. Riessen makes caramels that are chocolate flavored. I didn't waste too much time because of the different word lengths.

When I saw your reference to Northwestern, I thought your puzzle connection would be the clue for 17 Across. Alas not. But don't be dismayed! Go read about the Rose Bowl. You see, David Steinberg's Stanford Cardinal didn't play in the "Rose Bowl Game"; the team played in "the Rose Bowl Game presented by Northwestern ..."!

Anyway, that Northwestern reference in your preveal confused me, but then I saw the Martin reference.

If your guy asked David Steinberg's parents for the name of a Beatles song featured in a crossword, I think it would have to be WHEN I'M SevenTY FOUR because he passed SIXTY FOUR already. I checked his age in the court record.
Yeah, I looked askance at that one.  I don't like caramels, so RIESEN was a double No!

Martin, today was not a good day for the Northwestern football program.

As for the puzzle,I did like the J being used an an initial twice. One reference is nonsensical and the other to John.

Schokolade.

I had a problem with the frosting also. It sort of "curdled" when I added the marscarpone. Maybe my butter was too warm it was super soft had been sitting out all day. And the marscarpone was super cold.  Or perhaps it was the brand of marscarpone. I used WF 365. Perhaps I should have gotten the imported Italian one instead. I was going to beat it more but I was afraid it would only get worse. Regardless the cake has amazing flavor. Wish I had better understanding of the frosting.

First off, CalPERS is alive and well, so let's skip the past tense. In the second, yes, they had rocky times recently--during the, you know, wossname, GIANT CRASH that deregulation, lunatic and greedy speculation, and a Republican government's looking the other way and whistling caused.

And as for the little comments about welfare quesns, the actual fact is that Jerry Brown somehow got legislation passed that massively increases worker and employer contributions.

By the way, love the fantasy that the wealthy don't freeload, following in the clawd footsteps of Ayn Rand.

This plan sounds alot like CALPERS and other massive state pension funds which generated massive fees while under performing and leaving them underfunded vs future liabilities. They also had independent boards and fiduciary rules.

The flaws with the 401k programs are that 1) tax benefits strongly favor highest income households, 2) they aren't offered by many employers, 3) many of the plans that are offered have excessive fees and 4) there is no automatic savings discipline in the IRA alternative.

If everyone enjoyed the equivalent of a tax deferral in the 33% to 39% range for dollars saved as current high income workers do, there would be a lot more savers.

If all employers who don't offer 401Ks had to offer automatic contribution to IRAs just as they withhold taxes today, there would be a lot more savers, especially if the default was a small contribution amount.

If there were some simple low fee portfolio models of index funds based on risk preference, there would be a lot better long term investment gains on those savings.

While it is difficult for many households to save, the longest line in the grocery store is to buy lottery tickets and the casinos seem to be doing a steady business. When people believe their best chance of getting ahead is one of those two options, something is very badly wrong.

The privacy puzzle has three different aspects
- what the device actually does
- what the device can do
- what the public perceives the device as doing / being able to do.
The public perception is hard to control, especially because it's very difficult to get people to trust your assertions that what the device actually does is much much less than what it could be doing, and as with most technology, what it actually does probably is less than what many of the users would like it to be able to do.
Is there a network connection? Then it could be uploading every picture it takes and every sound it records (and there are applications, like Black Lives Matter protest recording and similar journalism where you'd want it to.)
Is there enough horsepower in the device you carry to actually do the voice transcription and imaging recognition, or does it upload them to a server in the cloud to do the hard work, like Siri and Android apparently do? If it gets to a server, the server can save anything it wants, but even if it's doing voice transcription on the phone, it could be uploading that very efficiently.

The big differences between this and Google Glass are that it's less visible to the people you might be observing (but a cellphone in your shirt pocket or on a jogging armband can do that too) and that the information it provides to the user is audio rather than visual (much cheaper to do, not always as useful.) Basically, it doesn't look like _bragging_, and Glass did.

For a shortcut, I used a store bought panettone, already with dry fruit, and made in individual ramekins, skipping the caramel base since panettone is already pretty sweet.  I used the proportions given for milk, cream, eggs and rhum (which is basically eggnog): delicious, but quite boozy.  I used half Captain Morgan spiced rhum and 1/2 Myers Dark.  I usually don't mind tasting the alcohol in desserts but this was too pronounced for many of my guests.  Next time I'll use French Negrita

They're aware of that and they're not the martyrs they make themselves out to be.  (ISIS, on the other hand...)

Excellent! i prefer the round dumpling skins. Minced cabbage and added carrot to up the vegetable content. Will process mixture further in the food processor next time. I already thought the veggies were too small, but I think red-lentil-sized pieces or smaller would be ideal.

I can't blame you if you're not aware of this (few Americans are) but there's far more discrimination evinced towards Hindus in Pakistan than there is towards Muslims in India.  Muslims remain a substantial minority in India.  Hindus in Pakistan represent a small fraction of the population and they've been mistreated on a continual basis since that nation was founded.

What do billionaires want? They want more. This isn't anything new. It's called wealth defence and goes back to the Middle Ages at least. What was the Magna Carta if not wealth defence by the barons?

The founders of our nation were very concerned about protecting wealth and rigged the system in favour of the rich by limiting the vote to male land holders and the electoral college was a firewall against the rabble electing the wrong man. For any of this to change Citizens United must be struck down and real campaign finance reform has to happen. If not forget about democracy. Unfortunately the mass of the population is either illiterate and uneducated or brainwashed. I have little hope.

Seems that a jalapeño or two might go well instead of the dried red chile.  Keeping in sync with the green theme.  Gonna try this out next week, mincing the peppers in the food processor with the other green stuff.

@ Lena Lingard,

You are correct, of course; but you're also laugh-out-loud funny in your spelling of the first word of your final line. It's even funnier to think of the copy editors cringing when they see that word! (I'm not talking about NYT copy editors; they apparently don't see the blog or the Comments. I'm talking about the copy editors who are part of the fun in the Comments section.)

As long as we're on the topic of pronouns and apostrophes, a story:

People at Sony Pictures Entertainment (a big movie studio) use email to communicate with people inside and outside SPE. Sometimes, the email accounts are "hacked" and the emails are released to the public.

This is a crime and should not be countenanced.

Anyway, some time back, a NYT Op-Ed columnist was preparing a thorough piece about gender discrimination in "Hollywood". She had an email exchange with the then-head of SPE, whose husband used to be a NYT reporter; both husband and wife are friends with the columnist. (For details, see the Public Editor's Journal entry for Dec. 12, 2014.)

In concluding their exchange, the head of the movie studio emailed the columnist, "I HOPE YOUR HAPPY!!!" along with affectionate personal remarks. The columnist wrote back, repeating the affectionate personal remarks, but writing, "I hope you're happy".

That exchange illustrates that NYT writers not only know how to spell contractions, but also that they resist using all caps when they write emails about gender discrimination.

It's even worse than that - the egg (another 60g) and even sugar count as liquid too.

Vs. Allen recipe they lost a few grams here and there in the conversions from metric to English and back to metric . She mentions that this is a very wet dough. But the main difference is that she calls for "strong" flour rather than all purpose. Strong flour is the UK equivalent of bread flour. Bread flour will result in a somewhat stiffer dough but it's still gonna be wet.

I just tried this and it was a disaster. The original recipe by Rachel Allen has a hydration (water divided by flour) of 67%, which is pretty standard. This one is 74%, which is like a wet ciabatta dough. I followed the directions and the dough was soup; it never came together. I added another 52 g flour to make it at least cohesive.

I'm wondering if first coating the flour with the butter somehow interfered with gluten development. That's a technique in making pastry, which I know nothing about, but I am an experienced bread-baker.

It is the most important reason in the world to vote, we need a democrat in the White House to appoint Supreme Court justices so we don't get anymore Roberts, Scalias and Thomas'.  There's still a chance to save this country but people have to go to the polls - there is no other way.
